title: Atelier HSL: Atelierhsl.nl
subtitle: Website
shortdesc: Atelier HSL is the arts and culture programme around the new Dutch High Speed Rail Line. The website functions as a medium where activities surrounding HSL are presented online: mainly art projects relating to the HSL.
longdesc: The concept for the interface is a matrix of points that symbolize the points on a map and the distance between them. Since the arrival of the HSL, time and distance becomes relative because of speed. Cities are drawn closer together: to a traveller, Amsterdam will be in a way more near to Paris than to a southern Dutch city such as Maastricht. By the expansion and contraction of the points of the matrix, areas are created for the content of the site. This expansion and contraction relates back to the idea of the relativity of time and distance.

media.title: Time table for the future trains

title: Digital Depot: DataCloud
subtitle: Interactive exhibition
shortdesc: Boijmans van Beuningen is a museum which collection is largely based on collections of art, gathered by collectioneurs. One of the goals of the digital depot is to give insight in how the collection is build up and the relation between the different works of art. The Digital Depot is a permanent exhibition space that features 2 main areas, the DataWall and the DataCloud.
longdesc: The second area, called the DataCloud, is a spatial visualization of the real-time database of the entire Boijmans collection (119,000 works of art). Each piece of art is represented by a point in a 3D space. All these points form a colorful universe, visually quantifying the extremely abstract term of '117,000 works of art' to the visitors of the museum. The space is defined by 3 axes: Date of Acquisition, Date of Manufacture and Format of Object. Through an intuitive interface the user can easily navigate through this 'universe' with a intuitive interface, he or she can specify the criteria by which the data is represented. The DataCloud will always display only the objects of art which fit this criteria. Clicking on a point in the cloud displays an image and detail information of the artwork selected. In this manner the user can gain insight on the make-up of the Boijmans collection.

title: Digital Depot: DataWall
subtitle: Interactive exhibition
shortdesc: Boijmans van Beuningen is a museum which collection is largely based on collections of art, gathered by collectioneurs. One of the goals of the digital depot is to give insight in how the collection is build up and the relation between the different works of art. The Digital Depot is a permanent exhibition space that features 2 main areas.
longdesc: The first area, the DataWall, showcases a revolving selection of 60-80 works of art presented on a large 2-sided wall. In front of these works of art are 6 free-standing panels of transparant glass which can display various information and digital content regarding the objects of art. This content is presented in highly interactive manner using an intuitive touch system. The deeper the user gets in the information the less transparant the glass panels become. In this manner the users focus will be guided from the wall to the information on the screens. This 'transparent' interface underlines the fact that the works of art themselves are the most important facet of the presentation and not the 'fancy' technology.

title: Margeting: Design Atlas
subtitle: Campaign for Global Shoes
shortdesc: The Design Atlas for Global Shoes is one of the campaigns LUST designed for the Margeting book.
longdesc: It’s an experiment in approaching design in a different way. Not from a marketing or communication point of view, but bottom-up. By starting at a wall of shoes and researching all connections between those shoes. Elements that were included in the final piece are for instance the countries where the shoes are made, marketshare, wall space, type of shoe, prices etc. In the end this would result in design ideas for outsoles, for uppers and for lacing patterns, all based on the original shoe wall.

title: Museum aan de Stroom (MAS)
subtitle: Design for inside walls
shortdesc: In the future, when you enter Antwerp the Museum on the Stream will shine on the horizon. Situated on the harbor, the museum will become a become a land-mark, a new symbol for the city Antwerp. The tower lighted the port district in the night with a gentle glow.
longdesc:
The concept, developed by LUST in cooperation with Karel Martens, for the inside walls carried out as light boxes of milk glass originates simply and connects on the concept of the architect, where the rooms are taken as a treasury for culture. Slightly pressing to the outside as if the museum shows its valuable contents. Outside the visually interesting possibilities, the relieved inside walls will also be skilful appliances at transferring all kinds of information which is interesting for visitors. Behind the glass routing information elements will guide the visitors, whereas the front of the milk glass function as a billboard, to announce exhibitions. Both from the street level as well as inside of the building large numbers give their own identity to each level of the building. The presented images show how light can give an identity to the building by simply having a computer program run different pre-programmed schemes.

This project was never executed.

title: Design Icons of the Post
subtitle: Website
shortdesc: TNT Post, the Dutch post company, has a long tradition of design. The website Icons of the Post is a virtual archive of the most remarkable designs that were made since the foundation of the company in 1799, from postal stamps to letterboxes.
longdesc: The base of the website is a database with an enormous amount of information about the objects and their context. One goal of the design of the website was to reveil all this information in a intuitive, exploring and well-organized way. Kind of getting lost without losing your way. This was done by creating a interface where the user never leaves the main screen. All requested information is reveiled by transforming the interface step by step.Another goal was to show the objects always in a context of their designer, their story of originate, their sketches, their (art) historic context and their relation to other objects. Also the website relates the objects of the past to the present, for example by automatically scraping rss feeds to search for topics about them. Playlists give the user a chance to save their own favourites and an extensive search function is also available. The website opens with a perspective view of all objects, showing the variety and diversity. Already in this stage the objects can be visually sorted by for example time or category. After choosing an object, the 'horizon' moves down and the information is reveiled. Related objects float just above the horizon. Color-coded links in the texts refer to related information, making menu-like lists superfluous. Clicking on a link slides in the new information, and when necessary new related information too.

title: Bits & Co Facade Lettering
subtitle: For Nemo
shortdesc: Nemo is a museum in Amsterdam displaying exhibitions on popular science. A new wing was opened which was to be used as a space where young people can learn and play with the most recent gadgets in digital and computer technology.
longdesc: LUST was asked to design a signage system that represented this digital world but also commented on the space. They decided to use a very well-known children's rhyme which all Dutch children are taught at a young age. LUST designed a sort of pixel font to set this rhyme with. When looked at from a straight perspective, one sees a representation of digital pixels and bits and bytes, but when seen from the ground floor one can begin to see the words appearing because of the phenomenon of forced perspective. A static signage but yet experienced in an interactive way: information design that acts as a learning tool.

title: glorad.nl
subtitle: Website
shortdesc: This project aims to create a spatial model of the discourse surrounding asylum seeking in the Netherlands. Weekly, articles about asylum seeking are automatically gathered form Dutch newspapers on the internet. Their content is analyzed to determine if the texts reflect a positive or negative viewpoint, then each article is visualized in the model.
longdesc:
Demands to contractors such as “It’s not supposed to be a four star hotel which would give the impression that the Netherlands are a paradise that is easily accessible” or “it is not supposed to be a gruff prison” either were conveying an ambivalent attitude by both political and public opinion in the design of these centers. Asylum seekers centers have been subject of debates, since the time the lodging of the asylum seekers got to be a problem. Their transitory and temporary quality reflects the living conditions of its inhabitants who are waiting for permission to join society or else to be deported to an unknown destiny. So this is basically a paradoxical affair mirroring the problems of seeking asylum on a local and national as well as a global scale. 

The project picks up these characteristics and tries to introduce this problematic into the realm of art and design as an ongoing process of design being at odds with available space under the influence of political opinions expressed through the media.

title: Hotel Oscar Echo Kilo...: Hoek van Holland Map
shortdesc: To highlight Hoek van Holland as the 'beach & water recreation area' of Rotterdam during 'Rotterdam 2001: Cultural Capital', a map was published which revealed the many facets of Hoek van Holland: historical, economic, industrial, residential, maritime, recreational, etc.
longdesc: In order to cover the broad scale of information the map became 2 meters long. To keep the map handy a folding system was devised that eliminated the trouble of having to continually fold and re-fold the map to see the necessary information. As a result, the map can be used as 4 maps of increasing detail: Hoek van Holland, the North Sea, Europe, and the World. Each folded variant shows information pertaining to that specific area, as well as showing the relation to the bigger area around it. On the other side of the map, the tidal and lunar information of Hoek van Holland is given for a complete year. A full moon is given a solid blue and a new moon 10% blue and all the steps in between are given it's respective decreasing or increasing percentages. Seen as a whole, the ebb and flow of the tides are symbolized.
client: Rotterdam 2001: Cultural Capital and OBR, Rotterdam

title: De Zee, het Strand, de Haven: TimeSlices
subtitle: Webcam Installation
shortdesc: In de Tussentijd (In the Meanwhile) was a series of workshops, an exhibition and a symposium about mobile urban planning in concurrence with the project The Sea, the Beach and the Harbour. The exhibition was set up around the presentation of the results of the workshops. The workshops are concerned with the concept of the mobile city. Themes were temporary building activities and vacant spaces in the city.
longdesc: The installation PAUZE consists of a timeslice. It is a sort of visual timeline of the changes of the beach area in The Hague. To do this they scraped an existing webcam and using a simple program, it took a pixel from the image at each specified time interval and added it to a new image. Notice the ebb and flood of the tides. Even the curvature of the earth can be seen (high and low tides on the horizon). Later other timeslices all over the world where made using the same principle.

title: De Zee, het Strand, de Haven: In the Meanwhile
subtitle: Exhibition
shortdesc: In de Tussentijd (In the Meantime) was a series of workshops, an exhibition and a symposium about mobile urban planning in concurrence with the project The Sea, the Beach and the Harbour. The exhibition was set up around the presentation of the results of the workshops The workshops are concerned with the concept of the mobile city. Themes were temporary building activities and vacant spaces in the city.
longdesc: The exhibition mainly consisted of a giant timeline, taking over three walls of the exhibition room. On this timeline most of the temporary architectural interventions in The Hague since 1860 were plotted. Every intervention was a sticker, pasted on the walls, in bright fluorescent orange, which glowed when projected upon. On one wall, on top of the timeline, a movie about these projects was shown. In this movie, every second was one month, thus creating a rhythm where sometimes objects would appear for a long time and others just for 2 frames. For this exhibition LUST also designed a TimeSlice.

title: Pages Magazine: Issue 1-9
subtitle: Magazine
shortdesc: Pages Magazine began in February 2004; a bilingual -Farsi/English- periodical pursuing an exchange between Iranian and international authors and artists with critical views on art, culture, urbanism and social issues.
longdesc: The central idea is to offer both languages equally without showing hierarchical preference (ie in typography, layout etc). So the magazine has 2 front covers depending on if you read the magazine as a Farsi or English reader. The english pages are always printed on the right side and the Farsi on the left. The content runs parallel to each other to avoid repeating images. In other words, the Farsi contents are the mirror (or reversed) of the English, and vice versa. In order to emphasize the continuing aspect of the magazine as a work-in-progress the pages are progressively page-numbered continuing further from each issue to the next. The first issue ends on page 32. The second issue begins with page 33, etc..

title: Inspiration: JPEG Fuckers
subtitle: Creating Mistakes
shortdesc: Since the beginning of LUST we have been interested in how to create unexpected results. One of the outcomes of this is what we call the JPG-Fucker.
longdesc: By opening up the file of a JPG in a text editing program you can re-arrange the code and by this re-arrange image elements in an image. You can do this to a certain extend. One of the JPG's we did this with turned out be be a sort of Magic JPG. When opened in PhotoShop it somehow remembers what is in the cache of PhotoShop and takes layers of that images and combines it with the current image. Thus creating a tool that designs for itself.

title: Logo Generator study
subtitle: Random Identity
shortdesc: The Netherlands is a densely populated country where issues concerning space have to be considered carefully. The aim of VROM is to make living, working, recreation and moving inside the Netherlands pleasant. The Ministry wants to stimulate inhabitants and companies in the Netherlands to approach issues on nature, environment and raw materials in a responsible way. The name VROM is the abbreviation of the Dutch name for housing, land-use planning and environmental management.
longdesc: LUST was approached by FHVBBDO to conduct a quick study in the viability of randomly generated logos. The word and type VROM were a given, LUST designed the way the logo could be randomized. Designers would get a little program that would generate on-the-fly elements of their identity. It was never implemented due to internal problems.

title: LSx: Look Right (Look Left)
subtitle: Symposium and exhibition
shortdesc: LSx is a two year research project by LUST at The Leeds School of Contemporary Art and Graphic Design at Leeds Metropolitan University. LSx focuses on the areas where urban planning, information and media technologies and graphic design overlap. It maps cultural and social development in Leeds to generate new systems of analysis, new data and information streams, and create organisational software for further research, recognising that there is no better source than the modern city with all its macro and micro layers of informational complexity. Each of the projects four phases will include a symposium for students, academics and professionals, comprised of lecture series, workshops and exhibitions, led by designers, artists, urban planners and cultural critics.
longdesc: The first LSx symposium had as its main focus an exhibition of contemporary work related to the themes of the symposium under the title Look Right (Look Left). This showcased contemporary works from 12 prominent designers, typographers, urban planners and artists to show the breadth of work in the merging fields of architectural and information processes and graphic design. It was not meant as a defining overview but rather as a tip-of-the-iceberg glimpse at some of what is possible.

title: LOOS: loosfoundation.com
subtitle: Website
shortdesc: LOOS was set up in 1982 under the leadership of composer/multi-instrumentalist Peter J.A. van Bergen, still director of the foundation. In 1996 LOOS became the LOOS Foundation. The activities of the LOOS Foundation are very difficult to place in a specific category or genre. They represent a musical idiom, a musical vision, and a relationship between music and society. Additionally, one of the most important characteristics of LOOS is its function in generating music (and music-related material) as an experience and experiment in form and content.
longdesc: The LOOS Foundation website is an experiment in visualizing music where silence is equal important to sound. Visitors navigate through the content while influencing the auditive and visual idiom by moving the mouse. At the beginning, no mouse movement means no sound, no visual. Then each next level builds up using new elements and elements of the previous level.

title: Inspiration: MacMame
subtitle: Digital Thrash
shortdesc: Since the beginning of LUST we have been interested in mistakes and random things. Around 1997 we found a lot of old Arcade Computer Games, which could be played on the Mac by a program called MacMame.
longdesc: This program emulates the original ROMs. Because the Mac works different then an arcade game, you could see the ROM checks, that normally would be invisible. These ROM checks turn out to be amazingly esthetic. Since that time we have been thinking how to use this. How can eighties computergames influence todays approach to mediadesign? Do you have to see the whole picture to understand it? Or is it possible to just see bits and pieces to get a clue?

title: North Sea Atlas
subtitle: Cartography of One of the Worlds Great Seas
shortdesc: The North Sea project consists of an atlas and a map. The map serves multiple purposes. The North Sea features on many urbanism agendas. This map wishes to play a role of significance when these agendas are discussed. Seas are intrinsically different from land - not just physically, socially too, and symbolically: mare is different from terra firma. Therefore we need to adopt and test a new type of cartography. In the way urbanism wants to be cultural urbanism, in that same way cartography becomes cultural cartography.
longdesc: The map aims first of all, to paint a picture of a small and, in geologic terms, youthful Inland Sea, which is at the same time a striking and multifaceted ‘World Sea’. That sea is described from 21 different points of view. As a consequence the map matrix is comprised of 21 distinct thematic maps: a seafloor map and a city map, a water map and a dirt map, a myth map and a scary map. The combination of these maps reveals intriguing links. This map, together with the grid map yields 421 unique maps. A sea that appears so empty yet is so full; full of the traces of man: ship wrecks, cables, pipes, conduits, oil rigs and, who knows, soon maybe even a massive invasion of ‘Monster Crabs’. The companion atlas contains 21 separate essays highlighting multiple cross-links. The atlas is illustrated with visual essays: 70 plus maps including historic ones from archives, new ones made by others as well as new ones hand-made for this project.
client: Self initiated project, with Jan de Graaf and Steven van Schutten

title: LUST: Bible
subtitle: Graduation projects

title: Margeting: Inventing a Different Marketing Language
shortdesc: The language used by marketing is getting bogged down in the structure of the narratives it generates. Experiences and objects are offered to consumers in unambiguous, immutable descriptions. Brands (which may also be programmes, ideologies or people) and consumers are captured in sharply defined frameworks and reduced to inflexible concepts. Marketing concepts eliminate anything that differs from the values they embody. As a result there is no place for ideas other than those that brand managers have named and turned into an identity and this includes ideas that matter to consumers. Brand managers want to keep on seeing the same things over and over again- they make language unambiguous.
longdesc: LUST designed the book starting with a 75 page index where all the words used in the text are indexed. This connects seamlessly to the whole idea Margeting is aiming at. The index is the most close you can get to non-hierarchy in a book form. Margeting generates narratives that do not dish up a single, stage-managed scenario, but keep on generating collections of ever-changing narratives from a predefined brand area: the brand as a crossroads of narratives! Only one font, in one size and one weight is used for the entire 512 pages. The multi-layered texts - from the main text, to notes, links and stories - all have there own place, but by the way it’s designed you will almost always read bits and pieces, therefore always in a way creating you own story.

title: Atelier HSL: Marking Europe High Speed
subtitle: Map
shortdesc: This New Map of Europe does not show “the new Europe”. The map is a new map. It gives us an impression of a Europe on the move. The map portrays a continent, on the edge of the Eurasian land mass, riven with frontiers and riddled with currents. Frontiers that shift, frontiers that fade. And currents that speed up or down, currents that change course.
longdesc: This Europe is a place that thrives on movement. It is entangled with the rest of the world by satellite links that reach beyond the stratosphere. The latest incarnation of that Europe, that of a Union, is in progress. It is a Europe which is expanding, and which at the same time wishes to grow in depth. The still unfinished map of Europe adds a layer to that depth. But which Europe? Is it the Occident of the Eurovision Song Contest? Or is it the Europe of the UEFA Cup, the Europe of the Euro, the Europe of the corporate logos, or Fortress Europe? Europa, the princess who was abducted by Zeus and on his back swam all the way from a North African beach to Crete, is still on her way. How long has Europe been in the water, and how much longer will it take to arrive? This map is the prototype for a new map in a contemporary guise - that of a digital atlas. In it, Europe is deciphered as a multi-layered landscape. The motive for this atlas is the construction of yet another layer: a ramified web of railway lines on which trains ride at higher speeds than ever before, the high-speed rail network. The location of this atlas is the means of transport itself, the high speed train.

title: TodaysArt: Mercury
subtitle: Mercure Hotel installation
shortdesc: This hotel, which is adjacent to the main town square is a major sponsor of the TodaysArt festival.
longdesc: Since the hotel is called Mercure, LUST decided to make the hotel the barometer of the virus, the 'mercury'. By simply changing the hotel into a lo-res tv. Each room got a separate red, green and blue lamp. The light intensity of each lamp was be controlled by a central computer. This effectively turned each room into a pixel of a color tv. Every visitor of the festival got a wristband with a unique 2D-Barcode. You could scan this code and leave your messages at the hotel (one letter was 35 meters high). The idea of controlling room lights for animations is not new but LUST takes it a step further by not only using the facade as a screen, but also use the three-dimensional aspects of the rooms in the final result.

title: Mondriaan Annual Report 2004
subtitle: Book
shortdesc: The Mondriaan Foundation was created to stimulate visual arts, design and the cultural heritage of the Netherlands. It's task is to strengthen the international position of contemporary visual arts and design by offering financial support to enable institutions, companies and authorities -both national and international- to reach their audience.
longdesc: The Annual Report gives information about all the projects they (co-)financed, totalling more than thousand projects which were supported for as little as a hundred and to as much as millions of Euros. A typographical system which separates different levels of information as a thread forms the lay-out of the pages, and divided by 3-ring pie chart that graphs exactly what they spend on each project. Every page is printed on a different color paper, in a random order which is unique to each copy of the report. There are 8 different colors for the cover and more than 20 different colors for the inside.

title: TodaysArt: MSSGBRD
subtitle: Filmhuis installation
shortdesc: For the TodaysArt festival 2005, The Hague art cinema (Filmhuis) transformed their public facade into a map and information screen. Without the budget for an LCD or LED installation nor the desire to use the window as an opaque screen (blocking the view of the town square below), an ad-hoc solution was used, that mixes low technology and high concept to maximum effect.
longdesc: By applying semi-opaque vinyl film squares in a grid pattern that represents The Hague, and using a standard high lumen projector, the facade could be animated simply. The resulting animations are easy and direct as well, since nothing needs to move, as only the individual vinyl squares light up, tracing current activity in the city. Festival information and live camera feeds were shown during the festival.

title: Atelier HSL: RailMovie
subtitle: Exhibition On Track
shortdesc: Atelier HSL is the arts and cultural programme around the new Dutch High Speed Rail Line connecting the Netherlands with the European Network of High Speed Lines.
longdesc: In RailMovie, a fully randomized program generates a never-ending landscape which simulates your view outside of a moving train's window. All objects are mathematically described - none was drawn. The randomizer chooses which combination of sky, horizon, land, clouds, cities, and poles and tunnels you see pass by. Each randomized view is shown for a random number of seconds before a new view is genereated and you pass through a new landscape. The graphical look comes from experiments in randomizing and tweeking code from JPG files, especially the Magic Jpeg, as described in the Mistakes section.

title: S+RO: Revolving Door NL
subtitle: Magazine for Urban Planning
shortdesc: For the cartography issue of S&RO Magazine for Urban and Spatial Planning, a map that visualized the total statistical data of immigration and emmigration to and from the Netherlands in the 20th century was needed.
longdesc: Because immi- and emmigration is about people and not about numbers, we deemed it necessary to find a way to represent each person symbolically as an individual. The solution was to show each immi- and emmigrant as a dot in a circular pattern which symbolizes the flow of people to and from Netherlands. Each track represents the part of the world from which the immi- and emmigrants come from. In this way one can easily see the concentration of people as people and not as abstract numbers. The final piece is a poster which was included as an insert in the magazine.

title: Risk Perception Carpet
subtitle: Exhibition on Data Visualization
shortdesc: InfoArcadia is an exhibition about data and information and the manner in which they are visualized. Information graphics, instruction manuals, information landscapes, data clusters, but also more personal ideas - like mapping one's life by marking events on food tin lids - were part of the exhibition.
longdesc: LUST was asked to make a piece which was an interpretation of the data Paul Slovic gathered in 1988 on people's perception of risks. 81 'risks' were chosen out of more than 40,000 questions from surveys regarding risk perception. A way was needed to be able to visualize the 'x-y matrix' on which the 'risks' were mapped. The end result is a visualization of three outcomes of the research: factors such as 'controllable vs. uncontrollable' and 'known risk vs. unknown risk'; the desire of people for strict regulation of certain risks; and the importance of certain risks as signals to society. The visitor would form the third axis (z). The carpet measures 4x4 meters.
client: Ronald van Tienhoven & Maarten de Reus at Stroom HCBK, The Hague

title: LOOS: Space Festival
subtitle: Posters and booklet
shortdesc: In continuation of the 1998 Speed Festival, the themes for the 1999 Space festival were Space & Spaces in the literal and abstract sense of the words.
longdesc: Some key ideas were: digital, repetition, patterns, order. The main concept of the printed material was a pattern of digital 8s which represented the grid of the whole piece. Each letter of the text is then superimposed on top if this pattern. A new font was designed for this purpose, which included the grid, as well as the individual characters. A square was also included as a character which blocks out the 8 thereby allowing to spell bigger text over multiple lines. LUST also designed a neon sign that reflected this concept: the idea is to overlap the blue argon tube with two more lines in green and red, that are all separately controllable via a computer, forming a new kind of white using the principles of RGB.

title: LOOS: Speed Festival
subtitle: Posters and booklet
shortdesc: The Speed Music Festival was one of a series of yearly festivals organized by LOOS in conjunction with KORZO Theater in The Hague. The festival centers around improvisational jazz, electronic music, and computer-generated melodies. The theme for the festival in 1998 was Speed.
longdesc: Some key ideas were: tempo, buzz, explosiveness, fragmentation, and fast/slow. The concept was to use the image of the shuttle Challenger explosion since everything about it (and space flight in general) reflected the theme. While fast-forwarding through an mpeg of the disaster, we noticed the video fall-out fragmenting the main image. The resulting black fields and lines of video noise also resembled the computer musical notation used by the musicians in the festival. This became the image for the poster which used the method of tiling. The idea to print the programme information on the rear of the poster adds to the idea of fragmentation even more once the posters were folded and sewn into books. Since the page numbers had to appear on the poster side as well, this in turn added the feel of a countdown to the image of the explosion.

It shows all characters at 12 pts. It was originally intended for a portfolio presentation for MacWorld magazine.

title: Stroom goes Underground
subtitle: Day of Architecture
shortdesc: The program of the Day of Architecture 2006 from the Art Centre of The Hague, Stroom The Hague, was about the underground and invisible The Hague. A lot of the hidden places were opened up for the day and tours and excursions were given to the secret and forgotten places.

Every element was printed in different shades of black, most of the time on top of each other and overlapping, thus creating a wide array of shades of black. title: Pages Magazine: Sunset Cinema
subtitle: Posters and postcards
shortdesc: In the waters of the Persian Gulf, eighteen kilometres off the southern coast of the Iranian mainland, lies the coral island of Kish. The master plan for Kish was initially developed before the 1979 revolution. The sun-splashed island has become a studio back-lot for an experiment into the limits of a more liberal attitude by the state.
longdesc: Amid this environment an international documentary film festival has been organised over the past five years, screening films with a realistic view of life on the mainland. The screening of these films on the island is interesting in so far as they introduce certain narratives of social consciousness into the escapist fabric of the island. Sunset Cinema proposes the construction of a cinema for the island that will host the documentary film festival and displace the economical and political attributes of the island into the architectural disposition of the cinema in Kish.

title: TodaysArt: Posters, flyers, program book
subtitle: Festival identity 2005
shortdesc: LUST puts new technology at the very center of its work and sees how they can influence and guide the form and look of whatever it is they are creating. In the case of the identity for TodaysArt, an art, music and technology festival, such a strategy seemed particularly appropriate.
longdesc: Using the idea of a virus as a means of replicating and spreading information as their inspiration and organizing principle, LUST created a generative program that was used to affect and guide all aspects of the festival identity: from the graphic language to the means of spreading information. The virus -represented in the color blue- resided on the festival website and could be viewed at all times. Installations throughout the city also served as barometers for the virus. Each generation of the virus was plotted and in this way, the growth of the festival and spread of information was tracked. The virus was symbolized as a grid – a grid that could be overlaid on the whole city, or just one building. Parameters were set up including hits to the website, number of visitors per venue, number of artists and performances playing, and the locations of interventions, and the data affected the grid.

title: Paradiso VIP Card
shortdesc: Paradiso, a club in Amsterdam, issues a limited-edition VIP pass to special members each year.
longdesc:
The concept was to print the pass on a business-card shaped cd-rom. The content of the cd-rom is a program that counted down the seconds until the membership expires. Reflecting Paradiso’s club roots, this program, as a bonus, is also a virtual Vj-Dj mixing panel containing beats, samples, and sound effects, as well as fragmentary animations and moving images. Each key of the computer’s keyboard contains 1 sound sample and 1 animation or image. By combining beats, melodies, and effects, one can play music and generate images as Djs and Vjs do. Since each image has transparent parts and each music sample is persistent, multi-layering effects can be fluidly achieved.

In cooperation with DesignArbeid, Amsterdam.

title: Volharding 1996, 1998, 1999
subtitle: Facade typography
shortdesc: This building was built in the early 20’s and was once the headquarters of the social cooperative De Volharding. The architect, Jan Buijs, designed the building with built-in illuminated signs on two facades.
longdesc: After a brief period of service, the signs were never used again after the 20’s. In 1996, Wils&Co -the architectural platform in The Hague- received permission to light up the signs on one side of the building to commemorate the opening of the National Week of Architecture. The design had to be of this time yet respecting the period in which the building was made. Since the initial use, we have continued to change the design each year for each new Week of Architecture. Starting in 1996 with quotes from architects, to the more poetic treatment of the surface of the building in 1999 (poem from the Dutch poet Lucebert). The design evolved in conjunction, from the ‘no-curves’ typeface Citizen from Suzanna Licko, to LUST typefaces made out of bitmaps (applying screen-based typography to the matrix of the building).

title: Volharding 2006
subtitle: Relighting the facade
shortdesc: This building was built in the early 20s and was once the headquarters of the social cooperative ‘De Volharding’. The architect, Jan Buijs, designed the building with built-in illuminated signs on two facades. After a brief period of service, the signs were never used again after the 20d.
longdesc: In 2000 LUST investigated the possibilities of using LED technology for the facades of the building, resulting in a report and series of proposals such as using this building as a cultural message board. In 2006, on the occasion of the TodaysArt festival they were finally able to re-light the building. Only now it resulted in a piece where also the audience could take part in, controlling and interacting with the building.

title: S+RO: Water Map
subtitle: Magazine for Urban Planning
shortdesc: Thirty two hundred seventeen glasses of water, the amount of drinking water an American uses per day. That are all the glasses in this graph, approximately 643,5 liter.
longdesc: This is ten times as much water that is available per person if we look at the whole world population. Less and less drinking water is available, because of polution, lowering of water levels, waste, sea level rising, changes in hydrological cycles and the growth of the popuation. Because of this, about 3 billion people in 2025 will live in countries that are scarce of water. It's ironic that moslty poor people in developing countries suffer the most from this. They don't have acces to safe drinking water and pay the highest price. More than two million people die yearly from water related diseases. These are social, economis, environmental and politiacal problems which should get the status of top-priority in the world. The organizations that are in charge of water in the Netherlands form the true ‘Polder-model’; from the national level, through the 12 provinces till local level, they all have to work together to keep the country dry.

title: Bike Maps
subtitle: Wateringse Veld, Leidscheveen, Ypenburg
shortdesc: In celebration of the Day of the Architecture in Holland, a set of cycling tour maps were published covering the special architectural projects built in the Vinex communities of the Hague.
longdesc: A matrix was designed as an index to help users quickly find either the streets where projects are found or the architects who built them. The street names form the y-axis and the architect's names forms the x-axis. Each architect is given a color, therefore making it simple to spot an architect and his project on the map. The color scheme of the matrix is defined by the alphabetical order of the street names thereby giving the matrix of each map a unique color fingerprint. The fingerprint of each matrix is then used as the cover panel for its respective map. All 3 fingerprints stacked on top of each other then forms the cover for the whole piece.

title: WorldSpectrumArchive
subtitle: Contribution Het Oog
shortdesc: The news, when read in a traditional manner provides information concerning a specific topic, but what does that information add up to? World/Spectrum/Archive is an investigation into the larger implications of world news viewed at a macro-scale. The sum of the current events of a country begins to speak of its condition both domestically and globally. World/Spectrum/Archive approaches this information from a linguistic perspective, evaluating the positive and negative connotations of the headlines of each country, resulting in an image of the state of the world on a given day.
longdesc: World/Spectrum/Archive pulls five news articles for every country in the world from Google news on a daily basis. By comparing ratios of the number of Google search results for a set of positive and negative words to the ratios of returned results for those words paired with the words in the headlines, the program can determine with eighty percent accuracy the semantic orientation of the each country's headlines. The results are then averaged by country and visualized both geographically and linearly, providing an image of how positive/negative the world is on a given day. The results are also archived, visualizing the shift in each country's orientation over time. An interesting and unexpected side-note of this project is that western countries tend to be the most positive, demonstrating the western-centricity of Google.

title: Scraper Type
shortdesc: How can a relatively simple concept as a font take advantage of the ever growing stream of information around us?
longdesc: Scraper is an application that uses Google News RSS-feeds to generate a typeface based on user input. When queried, Scraper searches for feeds related to the search-term and uses the results to populate the requested characters. Once created, it continuously generates unique sets of 5 weights –light, regular, medium, bold and black– from either the current data, or an archive of all previous results for the query.
client: NY Times and Graphic Design Museum

Initial presentation of the idea with images
Initial presentation of the idea for NY Times magazine, Year in Ideas, 2006
media.caption: Using a series of slider bars, pop-down menus and radio buttons, the user can then determine the formal qualities of the font. Some possible choices: Serif-Sanserif, Thin-Thick, Less Fill-More Fill, Loose Fill-Tight Fill, Fill Rotation, etc. The user then types some text into the application and generaties the lines of type he or she needs. Each letter is then filled with the scraped information that corresponds to his or her selections. Depending on the chosen source, the font can be filled with either text or images. Each letter is represented by the data that alphabetically corresponds to that letter. All in real time! A line of text typed today will always be different than that same line of text tomorrow. It is a snapshot of the world à la minute.

title: You are Here
subtitle: Open Ateliers campaign
shortdesc: Open Ateliers is the Open House of the Rijksakademie when the public can visit the studios of the artists attending the school. LUST was asked to design the posters, invitations and guide, but because of the complex nature of the building, the major complaint in years previous was that no one could find their way to all of the studios.
longdesc: Therefore we proposed to take the routing as the main strategy to solve the problem and that solution would automatically design the print work at the same time. The concept to use a metro-like map with the floor markings of institutions such as hospitals lead to the main graphic element of the print work - floor-tape. A map was therefore designed which lead the public around the building literally direct to the studio of choice: no one got lost.

title: Zandstad: Zandstad Re-ordered
subtitle: Maps
shortdesc: Zandstad (SandCity) is the (fictional) region around Eindhoven in Noord-Brabant, a province in the south of The Netherlands, which is on the verge of being restructured. From a mainly agricultural to a more diversified area. The project is a test case in working with a cultural biography for an area, bringing together all kinds of historical aspects, ranging from architecture and landscape, to religion and occupations. Eventually designers and historians work together to come up with new ideas for a region like this.
longdesc: The cartography for Zandstad should provide inspiration and new gazes on the area itself. It plays with the idea that maps tell lies. People who look at maps often don't realise that a map is an abstraction of reality, where a lot of choices have to be made because of the scale something is depicted. The cartography made for Zandstad does deliberately lie, by isolating data and plotting them in the way it tells the story we want it to tell. A good example are the re-ordered satelite photo's of the area, which are now ordered on the basis of the use of the soil (for example forest, water, agriculture, city, village, roads, grass land etc.). This provides another image of an area which is usually looked at as a totally (sub)urbanized area.
client: The Netherlands Architecture Fund, Rotterdam, and the VU, Amsterdam

title: World Skin Color
subtitle: In Your Face exhibition, Centraal Museum Utrecht
shortdesc:
“Imagine people as color pixels; you would fly over the world, look down and see what? Through migration, mixed marriages, wars, trains, planes and automobiles the skin color map of countries and cities continuous to change all the time. With the help of the world fact book Reineke Otten gathered data to create so-called skin color maps. Looking at them you can read history. White dots in South- Africa, an amalgamation of faces and races in Brazil and workers in Dubai. Meanwhile tourist visit the Bahamas to get some tan, Chinese women spends their money on whitening creams.”

For the exhibition In Your Face in the Centraal Museum Utrecht, LUST developed a new series of maps based on research done by Reineke. Variering from UV-radiation to Migrants, and Urban and Rural, 5 large maps that were printed on silk were devised, plus a series of 25x220 unique country maps, revealing different aspects of issues related to World Skin Colors.  

World Skin Colors is a long term project by Reineke Otten. A part of this project was also on display at Museum de Paviljoens, at the exhibition De Kracht van Heden 2011-2012.

title: Form+Code
subtitle: in Design, Art and Architecture
shortdesc: Together with Casey Reas (Processing) and Chandler McWilliams LUST developed the book and site Form+Code in Design, Art and Architecture, published by Princeton Architectural Press. The publication discusses the role of software in visual design, art, and architecture. It hopes to generate interest in creating visual and spatial form with software across diverse fields by focusing on the history, theory, and practice of software in the arts.
longdesc:
The book is about one fourth text and three fourths images and is organized around two parallel narratives: one told through images and captions, and the other through essays with related diagrams and images. This allows the book to be read cover-to-cover or leisurely looked through as a source of inspiration. 

The first two chapters set the foundation for the rest of the book by discussing the history of the computer in the arts and how software is used to create form. The five themes of repetition, transformation, parameters, visualization, and simulation are deeply linked to code. Each of these sections begin with an essay to define the territory, continues with images and captions, and concludes with code examples. Form+Code is not a programming tutorial; its goal is to inspire though the discussion of themes and projects. Each chapter starts with a paragraph set in a specially designed typeface, that does not exist as a typeface, but is programmed. The code generates the form, and this form will be different with each combination of letters. The book is available at Amazon.

title: RGB City
subtitle: Belgrade
shortdesc: A new landmark for Belgrade? A building that seems to be alive, each room filled with lights that not only change color but also direction.
longdesc: During the Dis-Patch festival a large-scale interactive light installation was installed in the building. Networked robolights (computerized spinning lights seen often in clubs) are placed in each room of the building. The intensity, color, and state of each robolight are controlled by a central computer, effectively turning each room into a pixel of a very low-ress color tv. Because of the flexibility of the robolights, the building and the physicality –especially the three-dimensional aspect– of the architecture is highlighted in a spectacular way. On the first night of the festival, the lights react to the music played in front of the building in a one-off performance. The spinning and flashing robolights turn the building into a swinging and swaying beacon for the festival, controlled via a touchscreen by visitors of the festival. Transforming Belgrade from White City to RGB City.

title: Lost & Found
subtitle: Poster and leader
shortdesc: Lost & Found is a legendary found and other footage programme. Since 1997, over 75 sessions of stray images and sound have been organised.  Artists show material which doesn't fit comfortably into regular gallery contexts; work which demands more concentration than the usual walk-by.
longdesc:
LUST designed the poster/invite as a typographic poster, consisting of scenes from the movie Lost Highway, by David Lynch.

The leader for the evening used the same principle, only now each frame really plays the scenes from the movie. The audio consists of the audio with each frame, layering on top of each other, forming an abstraction of the original soundtrack.

title: Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam
subtitle: Identity Proposal
shortdesc: In 2008 LUST was asked to enter the competition for a new identity for the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam. We entered the competition because the brief, to develop a system of signs was an interesting one. We feel that the position of the designer has been defined for a long time: we are the producers of structured communicative visual forms and identities – stimulating our society’s signs and symbols to new interpretations. This view of the designer’s role is not necessarily defunct – it is just shortsighted in light of recent developments in our culture. This paradigm shift can be simply described as previous linear models being replaced by non-hierarchical ones.
longdesc: The main idea was to not only develop a corporate identity but also an identity that functions as a cultural identity. Key question was how you could create an identity that is totally based on content? Our proposal revolved around the idea of developing a meta-language, a new language for the museum, so that you can read and write “Stedelijk”. This language used different scales; scales of content, time and space. Meaning for instance that the messages the museum “broadcasts” would change form, meaning and complexity, depending on the scale or distance to the museum. Keeping in mind that everything should be site- and context-specific and using on-demand modes of production. This resulted in an initial system that uses a circle-form with different words that have their own meaning, but can be read in all directions, constantly forming new micro-sentences. This form could change over time, but the main idea would stay: the content becomes the medium, the content is the interface and over time -just like a real language- a vocabulary is developing and growing. The proposed idea is not an identity in a traditional sense, but tried to define what an identity could be in a not too far away future.

title: Graphic Design Museum: Poster Wall for the 21st Century
subtitle: 100 Years of Dutch Graphic Design
shortdesc:
On the occasion of the opening of the new Graphic Design Museum in Breda (NL) the Poster Wall for the 21st Century was launched, both online and as a part of the museum’s permanent installation '100 Years of Graphic Design in the Netherlands'.

In the museum 600 unique posters are automatically generated daily using content gathered from various internet sources. Online, one new poster is generated every five minutes. New posters are automatically generated when physical events occur in the space: for example, when visitors enter the space, when visitors view the touchtables, and when visitors approach the wall itself.
longdesc:
Using a complex “content scraping, analysis, and designing” algorithm, the posters contain content covering a range of topics such as cultural events, news, weather, etc, and are constantly generated and updated. The posters always contain the most current and relevant information on an hourly basis.

It attempts to provide insight into the direction graphic design might go in the future while posing the question: “What is the role of statis media in the future and what is the future task of a graphic designer therein?”

Live-versions of the posterwall have been shown at the 2010-2011 Triennial of Design at the Cooper Hewitt in New York, at the Wide White Space exhibition in Wattis, San Francisco and Public Design Expo in Seoul. Each itteration offering new possibilities, like Tweets, QR-codes, and social sharing.

title: Graphic Design Museum: 100 Years of Dutch Graphic Design
subtitle: Interactive exhibition
shortdesc: Voor het Graphic Design Museum bedacht, ontwierp en programmeerde LUST de interactieve elementen. Centraal staat het ‘bezoekersvolgsysteem’. Gedurende de gehele tentoonstelling, verdeeld over 3 zalen worden bezoekers door middel van bewegingssensoren ‘gevolgd’. De tentoonstelling reageert hiermee op de aanwezigheid en looproute van de bezoekers, een interactiviteit die gaandeweg het traject toeneemt. Zo geeft de expositie commentaar op de ontwikkelingen in onze samenleving en de rol die enerzijds technologie daarbij speelt en anderzijds de invloed van de eindgebruiker zelf.
longdesc:
Aan dit systeem werden naast de verlichting, geluid en diashows in totaal 9 interactieve tafels met touchscreens en 2 grote interactieve projecties gekoppeld. De verschillende vormen van interactie hebben ten doel de bezoeker niet alleen verdiepende informatie over de tentoongestelde objecten te bieden maar laten tevens zien hoe de eindgebruiker zelf invloed uit kan oefenen op de manier waarop deze informatie wordt overgebracht. Het gaat niet om een herinterpretatie van informatie naar het niveau voor consumptie (deconstrueren) maar het opnieuw organiseren en structureren van de gegevens en de eindgebruiker zo het gereedschap te bieden om het op zijn of haar eigen manier te interpreteren. Hedendaags ontwerpen is minder geïnteresseerd in de formele eigenschappen van een ontwerp (kleur, vorm, typografie) en meer in de methode waarop inhoud gegenereerd, gestructureerd en verspreid kan worden. 

De interactieve tafels in zaal 2 en 3 activeren zichzelf zodra een bezoeker in de buurt komt. Wanneer er geen bezoekers zijn gaat de interface terug naar een ‘nulstand’ voor een volgende bezoeker. Navigatie vind plaats met de hand of vinger en wordt uitgebreid naarmate de bezoeker verder is in de tentoonstelling. Het bouwt op van informatielagen in de z-as, de x- en y-as en tenslotte in alle assen. Er is uiteraard getracht zo min mogelijk gebruik te maken van buttons en in plaats daarvan het materiaal zelf op een intuïtieve manier als navigatiemiddel te gebruiken.

De interfaces in zaal 3 zijn gebaseerd op interviews met de zeven tentoongestelde ontwerpers. Om deze interviews van ieder ongeveer 17 minuten behapbaar te maken zijn zij onderverdeeld in zeven thema’s van het ontwerpproces. Het videomateriaal wordt als een stapel kaarten van alle losse beelden weergegeven. Hierdoor wordt een visuele preview van het gehele videofragment zichtbaar en krijgt de bezoeker een indruk van de lengte van het fragment. Dit laatste maakt een vergelijk mogelijk waar voor welke ontwerper de nadruk ligt in het ontwerpproces. Door het fragment aan te raken begint het te spelen (en wordt de stapel langzaam kleiner), door met de hand of vinger langs de stapel te bewegen ‘scroll’ je door de video heen. Daarnaast kan de bezoeker de stapel verplaatsen, uittrekken en vergroten en tenslotte alle fragmenten op elkaar stapelen.

De projectie in zaal 3 (Poster Wall for the 21st Century) is een dynamische wand die vanuit talloze internetbronnen affiches genereert van o.a. culturele evenementen, nieuwsberichten, webcams, het weer en de tentoongestelde thema’s. Elke dag worden er door het systeem automatisch volgens een algoritmisch proces tussen de 500 en 600 nieuwe, unieke posters gemaakt welke geactiveerd worden door de positie(s) van de bezoeker(s). Hiermee wordt als afsluiting van de tentoonstelling de vraag opgeworpen welke (maatschappelijke) rol de ontwerper in de (nabije) toekomst op zich kan/moet nemen. 

Exhibition design by Kinkorn, Tilburg.

title: De Zee, het Strand, de Haven
At Random? Exhibition
subtitle: Interactive Media Installation Iris
shortdesc: At Random? Networks and Cross-pollinations, was an exhibition curated by the Museum De Paviljoens in Almere, Netherlands. As its point of departure, At Random? takes the idea that creative processes – now more than ever – do not evolve linearly but in an associative and unpredictable way. At Random? is inspired by the enormous offering of information that is produced on a daily basis within our media society. At Random? deals with interdisciplinary cross-pollinations, networks and new sources of inspiration for the artists, designers and curators that are involved in the exhibition. LUST was invited to be part of this exhibition and, at the same time, design the exhibition design and all the related print collateral.
longdesc:
To play off the idea of randomness, LUST proposed to print all the paper needed throughout the course of the 6 month long exhibition to be made at the beginning of the exhibition, using a printing process known as ‘split-fountain’ printing (irisdruk in Dutch). This technique involves printing multiple colors on the same roll during a single print run, effectively mixing the colors in gradient on the fly.

The total of 80.000 A3-sized sheets was exhibited in the museum, as a paper sculpture, in 10 stacks of 8000 sheets. This paper was to be also used for the digital copier in the installation which printed, collated and bound each on-demand piece. Through a specially devised program, visitors could print their own unique copy of the exhibition catalogue, for example, which always had a different lay-out according to the program in the digital copier. Also all the posters, invitations, museum texts were printed on this paper. The stacks functioned as kind of timeline, since the paper dwindled as the paper was used for the show. The paper on which each piece was printed could be then related back to the time of the exhibition it was printed.

title: Generation Random
subtitle: Exhibition celebrating 10 years LUST
shortdesc: The tenth anniversary of LUST was celebrated with a month of events at the <>TAG Gallery in The Hague. LUST presented a decade of design in an interactive visual catalogue that explored new forms of archiving. The exhibition was not aimed at summing up 10 years of a graphic practice, it strived instead to highlight the actual process of design in which failure and success exist side by side. It addressed the issue of data storage, access, exchange and modification that has become increasingly relevant in the digital age.
longdesc:
Accessibility and storing of data has always been an issue of scientific interest. Before 1990, information was mostly stored in physical archives, either on paper or on microfilm. One of the great pioneers in the field of data accessibility was Paul Otlet, who founded the Mundaneum in 1910; a library with over 12 million 7,5x12 cm index cards and documents. In the desperate struggle to cope with the overflow of published information, Otlet laid down the basis for what we now know as the Internet. His aim was no less than to create an archive of humanity’s collective intellectual capital, made accessible by a system allowing users to find data at the most specific level. The Digital Revolution has accellerated the development of data storage and accessibility at tremendous speed. One of the key changes of representing data, which Otlet had already predicted, is the lack of hierarchy that allows the free exchange of information between different users.

Bearing all this in mind, LUST created an exhibition where all displayed projects reveal a great interest in the area where non-linear information structures and process methodologies fuse with the craftsmanship of the typographer or designer. The result was a media installation that featured an interactive multi-touch table, a shelf of archival boxes and a roll-fed printer – a virtual LUST studio in situ. The 50 archival project boxes mirrored the real-world archival system used at the LUST studio and was the medium by which the LUST works were presented in exhibit. By placing a box from the shelf onto the table, the content of the box is revealed as media on the table. The user could then explore projects and manipulate them. A tagging and keyword system guided the user through a myriad of crosslinks which are intertwined throughout the projects. Every minute, the currently manipulated image on the touch table is printed onto a continuous roll as a one centimeter strip. This resulted in a thirty meter long browsing history of the entire exhitition – a timeline for Generation Random.

title: Fortress Europe
subtitle: East of Eden book
shortdesc: Every year thousands of refugees are trying to flee to Europe in their search for safety from persecution, for economic security or just ‘a better life’. Each year hundreds of them drown on the way from Africa to Italy or Spain, suffocate in sealed containers, starve in locked trucks, are blown to pieces by land mines between Turkey and Greece or freeze on their way over the mountains. And if they finally manage to arrive in “Fortress Europe” they are not at all safe. They are fenced-in, in refugee centres, some of which do not differ from a normal prison. Some of these refugees cannot deal with the misery and the inhuman conditions in which they are held and start a hunger strike or sew their eyes and mouth shut to protest against their situation. Some of them even commit suicide. Although many European states celebrate the lowest numbers of refugees in years, people still plea for stricter rules and limitations for refugees.
longdesc:
It is at least ironic that the origin of the name “Europe” is the legend of Europa who was abducted by the Greek God Zeus in the form of a bull. He swam with this Middle Eastern princess upon his back from a beach in Canaan to his island, Crete. This story is often referred to as ‘the rape of Europa’. Nowadays, Canaan is named Lebanon, situated on the Asian continent. When we started this project it was based on a list with 11105 refugee deaths. The time it took to make the maps, the list grew over 13000. History seems to continue the same way it always did. 

The map depicts one refugee as one line. By doing this, it actually forms gray surfaces from many countries because of the amount of refugees.

connections.title: Women's Political Rights Around the World

title: Oogle
shortdesc: Oogle is a search engine, created for 'Oog', visual columns for De Volkskrantnewspaper. The search engine queries Google search and determines the semantic orientation of each word in the returned results. To determine semantic orientation the program searches every word in the title and description of each result.
longdesc:
By comparing the number of returned Google search results for each word to the ratio of returned results for a set of positive and negative words to the number of returned results for the positive/negative words paired with each word, the program can determine the degree of positivity or negativity. Essentially word score is determined by how often it is found paired with other words known to be positive or negative. Each word in the returned results is then colored by score, and the scores visualized per result title, result description, and then for the whole page, showing the overall semantic orientation as determined by Google.

Oogle is a tool for digital anthropology in that it gives insight into the relationship between language and (primarily western) culture and shows how, at a certain moment in time, words are being read and valued.

connections.title: Women's Political Rights Around the World

title: Public Information Bubble (P.I.B.)
shortdesc:
The first extended broadcast of the human voice was transmitted through the air on December 24, 1906 from Brant Rock, Massachusetts by Reginald Fessenden, a Canadian engineer who had worked for Thomas Edison in his New Jersey Laboratory. An account by Fessenden's wife Helen recounts his historic transmission, as witnessed first-hand by countless radio operators on ships across the Atlantic:

"...a human voice coming from their instruments - someone speaking... Then a women's voice rose in song. It was uncanny! Many of them called their officers to come and listen; soon the wireless rooms were crowded. Next someone was heard reading a poem. Then there was a violin solo; then a man made a speech."
longdesc:
Since that historic broadcast, we have been transmitting our personal narratives non-stop out the world to hear, adding to the growing stories within the earth’s own Personal Information Bubble (P.I.B.). Since Fessenden’s first broadcast in 1906, all these narrative left the earth and is headed to the outer reaches of space at the speed of light. Today the P.I.B. has expanded to include internet and mobile media sources such as Twitter, Facebook, Foursquare, MSN, Skype, and SMS, documenting the daily minutiae of the earth’s citizens. Every tweet, blog post, news feed, and text message contribute to the expansion of the P.I.B. But what do these narratives say about us as a society and culture?

Through this two part media and architectural installation, LUST attempts to visualize this bubble from the perspective of the gallery and headquarters of the GDFB, the former printing office for the provincial newspaper BN deStem.

Using the spectrum of light to visualize the information density of all the data the P.I.B. contains, the individual colors culminates in a gigantic white beam streaming towards space. The intangible narrative of the P.I.B. symbolized in the subtractive color process of light. Inside the gallery, a large printer endlessly documents these same narratives on a continuous roll of paper. The random colors of each letter of each personal narrative documented on this ‘scroll’ gradually mix to black when viewed from a distance. Through additive color process, the words ends up as a black news stream, a poetic juxtaposition to the white light of the building.

title: ASV Arsenal
subtitle: Good Vibrations
shortdesc:
LUST was asked to participate in an art project for ASV Arsenal in Amsterdam. About 10 artists were asked to develop ideas for art interventions. LUST developed various ideas, varying from digital to analog.

In the end the project turned to the most ultimate and simple solution, a football loaded with technology, able to register everything the ball did. When the footballers were playing, a soundscape is created, reacting to every tiny movement the ball makes. Also all information is stored, so after the match, data visualisations can be made that deal with all movements of the last 90 minutes.
longdesc:
According to FIFA, the history of games revolving around the kicking of a ball go back to the third centuries BC in China. At the turn of the 21st century football is played by over 250 million players in over 200 countries making it the world's most popular sport. While most players are just having fun, sometimes football seems to be to much about money, winning and rivalry. LUSTlab's goal to connect the physical world to the digital lead to the development of an interactive football, which on one hand encourages playfulness and on the other hand provides new insights in ball movements.

Things like the speed of a ball go when you kick it, how does it rotate and accelerate, can a player keepy uppy 50 times in a row; these are all parameters you can measure when placing sensors inside of the ball. These sensors react to movement. Each kick, turn, bounce is registered and transmitted wirelessly to a computer or smart phone.

All this measured information can be used to generate visualisations which can be shown in real-time on screen. These visualisations can also be used for analysis and later to archive all the played games.

To demonstrate the possibilities of this technology LUSTlab developed an interactive football for the art project 'Terreinwinst' for the Amsterdam football club ASV Arsenal. The movements made with the football are linked to sounds that enhance the original atmosphere. For the art project, these sounds were sourced from well known movie soundtracks. The samples were played through quadrophonic speakers arranged on each corner of the field. Because of the rapid way the game is played, every kick and bounce turns the game into a unique soundscape and playing becomes a whole new experience.

This new technology will bring football back to the core of the game: hitting the ball and the effect it has on the game. The next step will be developing the technology and exploring the data it delivers. This can be with a focus on stimulating the game from a leisure point of view but also integrating the technology into training sessions, both professional and amateur. 

Good Vibrations is a LUSTlab project

title: NewsSpectrum
subtitle: iPad app
shortdesc: The news, when read in a traditional manner provides information concerning a specific topic, but what does that information add up to? NewsSpectrum is an investigation into the larger implications of world news viewed at a macro-scale. The sum of the current events of a country begins to speak of its condition both domestically and globally. NewsSpectrum approaches this information from a linguistic perspective, evaluating the positive and negative connotations of the headlines of each country, resulting in an image of the state of the world on a given day.
longdesc:
NewsSpectrum pulls five news articles for every country in the world from Google news on a daily basis. By comparing ratios of the number of Google search results for a set of positive and negative words to the ratios of returned results for those words paired with the words in the headlines, the program can determine with eighty percent accuracy the semantic orientation of the each country's headlines. The results are then averaged by country and visualized both geographically and linearly, providing an image of how positive/negative the world is on a given day. The results are also archived, visualizing the shift in each country's orientation over time. An interesting and unexpected side-note of this project is that western countries tend to be the most positive, demonstrating the western-centricity of Google.

Based on the NewsSpectrumArchive site, LUST developed the NewsSpectrum App for iPad. 

Will be available in the App store soon.

Programming by Nooitaf.

title: TodaysArt: Blue Light District
shortdesc:
Turning the city of The Hague into a Blue Light District.

Taking the lights of THX: The Hague Int'l as an inspiration, LUST created an identity and theme for 2008's TodaysArt festival. The program booklet is ordered chronologically, using a gradient to indicate the time of day (light to dark). This way, also the edge of the book gives a hint where information can be found. Also the program and editorial pieces are integrated seamless because that run simultaneously. 

Giant lights that light up the buildings in the Grote Marktstraat, one of the main streets in the city center of The Hague. The buildings are used as pixels, creating an enormous effect of depth in the street. Controlled by a simple Processing script and allowing for interaction with passers by.

title: Posterwall 2.0
shortdesc:
For the Graphic Design Museum in Breda we developed in 2008 the Poster Wall for the 21st Century, both online and as a part of the museum’s permanent installation '100 Years of Graphic Design in the Netherlands'.

In the museum 600 unique posters are automatically generated daily using content gathered from various internet sources. Online, one new poster is generated every five minutes. New posters are automatically generated when physical events occur in the space: for example, when visitors enter the space, when visitors view the touchtables, and when visitors approach the wall itself.

Live-versions of the posterwall have been shown at the 2010-2011 Triennial of Design at the Cooper Hewitt in New York, at the Wide White Space exhibition in Wattis, San Francisco and Public Design Expo in Seoul. This 2.0 version of the Posterwall offered new possibilities, like Tweets, QR-codes, and social sharing.

The Posterwall is currently travelling accross the USA and was already exhibited at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, the Cooper Hewitt in New York, the Hammeer Museum in LA and is currently on display in Grand Rapids.

Some media coverage:New York Times, FoxNews (yep, we know...), Startribune, Minnesota Public Radio, Gallerist, LA Review of Books.

If you are interested in the technique behind this (a series of connected Kinects), take a look here!

title: Urban Echo
shortdesc:
Now that we are familiar with being connected digitally, the physicality of our interactions becomes important again. The globalised communication systems we use everyday exist on a level above our tangible surroundings.

Urban Echo brings some of this communication back to real locations, connecting public places and therefore people, cities and cultures. It extends space beyond our once concrete parameters. Webcams allow you to see into another space, mirrors allow you to see your own space. Using billboard screens and cameras, Urban Echo creates a hybrid of these two things, allowing not only see into another city but maybe see yourself transported into another city or culture. A mid point between transparency and reflection, introspection and extrospection.

Placed in public areas, the screens have a variety of modes. Sometimes they create a recursive loop allowing interaction between people in multiple cities and sometimes they are just a window to another place, that might intrigue a passer by. They can connect regardless of distance, folding locations together and rearranging our perspective of public space.

Urban Echo is a LUSTlab project

title: Berlage Institute
subtitle: Various Works
shortdesc:
The Berlage Institute is a post-academic laboratory for design-based research in architecture, urbanism, and other issues related to the built environment. Its postgraduate program and PhD program are open to applications from graduated and experienced architects, urban planners, landscape architects, and other researchers. Complementary to these programs, the Institute also broadens its activities to the professional sector with a series of publications, for which it solicits internal and external collaborators, and a public program of lectures, debates, and symposia.

Next to the website, which functions as an internal file-archive as well, and includes live-streaming, video archive, calendar of events etc., LUST also designed various printwork for symposia, invitations, the Berlage Papers, posters, and a number of prospectusses. All items look different, but all together form a coherent series. 

In 2012, the Berlage Institute has revived itself and is now part of the TU Delft and is now called The Berlage

title: PolyArc
subtitle: Media Installation
shortdesc:
During the 22nd International Poster and Graphic Design Festival of Chaumont, LUST (NL) took over the Chapelle des Jésuites with an in-situ piece intended to build bridges between the Festival’s past and future. Extending the notion of archiving to the future and to hypothetical pasts. 

Prior to the exhibition, they compiled a visual and textual database. Visitors at La Chapelle could interact with this ‘polyarc’ to make their own digital or print publication, before adding their own contributions to it.

Through its content, the installation explores and informs us about graphic design in Chaumont: venues, accomplishments and projects. Through its form, it considers the paths and media travelled by graphic design; and how they are evolving in light of technology, the amount of information and images being produced, and changes in the applications of the discipline. 

During the festival visitors could pick up one-of-a-kind print-on-demand booklets  at La Chapelle which could be inserted into this dossier. This dossier functions as a ‘snapshot’ of a constantly growing archive. Visitors were invited to contribute to this archive by sending Twitter messages. Any messages sent will be stored and made accessible via the installation and printed for the dossiers.

title: I Read Where I Am
subtitle: Exploring New Information Cultures
shortdesc: When contemplating what the future of reading may mean, it is one thing to ponder the physical or habitual aspects of reading but another to consider the shifts in the manner in which texts and literature, and therefore reading, are contextualized. Words and phrases may contain meanings extending past what the author attributes in his or her narrative. For example, temporal or location-dependent contexts may play an increasingly significant role in today’s texts.
longdesc:
Literary anthropology, as defined by literary theorist Wolfgang Iser, suggests that while the reader will always have an interpretation of the text he or she reads, the interpretation itself participates in the ongoing development of the reader’s self identity. Literary anthropological research is therefore organized by the belief that a relationship to a literary text can become an interesting point for the continued interpretation of culture and the way culture is weighted.

As graphic designers, we are interested in the interpretive practices associated with these reader/text relations. In the past, literary theorists have used literary analytical devices (i.e. codes) to critique literature in order to denote the function of various semantic apparatus. We, as designers, can also use similar methodologies to lay bare the semantic structure of a piece of text.

Except, instead of using literature as our medium, we at LUST prefer to use the ever-growing stream of data we, as a digital society, produce. And instead of using literary methods of critical analysis, we can use self-designed digital tools such as (computational) code, algorithms, and databases to mark large sets of text at a more empirical level. Each time a previously annotated ‘narrative’ is re-visited—or marked—the context of the last reading changes, therefore also affecting—or changing—the current reading as well. Using similar recursive methodologies, a codex of data (or millions of points of entry) can be developed which supports any research query or interest.

It is this aspect of reading that we have attempted to contextualize in the design and typography of this book. For example, words are colour-coded in a gradient from dark (more) to light (less) as a comparative value of frequency versus uniqueness. Also, several indexes are featured as random access interfaces to the articles. And finally, the subject matter in the texts is extended beyond the book through comparisons with Wikipedia entries of similar semantic meaning (micro- versus macro-context). So in essence, in the conceptualization of this book, we are not only trying to produce graphic and typographic design. But, by augmenting code and form with critical language theories, we are also practising what we like to call Digital Anthropology.
